metadata.title: Swollen-induced <ce:italic>in-situ</ce:italic> encapsulation of chiral silver catalysts in cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers: Homogeneous reaction and heterogeneous separation

111901 S2468-8231(21)00518-6 10.1016/j.mcat.2021.111901 Fig. 1 Several strategies for the heterogenization of homogeneous molecular catalysts (Previous work) and our conceptually new strategy (This work) with encapsulation of chiral catalysts in cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Images of the desired polysilicone-encapsulated Ag catalyst through swollen-induced approach: (a) polysilicone elastomers which fabricated by hydrosilylation reaction of vinylsiloxane and PMHS in the presence of Karstedt's catalyst; (b) The cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers absorbed with Et2O after swelling in Et2O, and the diameter has doubled from 1 cm to 2 cm; (c) The encapsulation of AgOAc in the cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers to form black Ag@Silicone material; (d) The polysilicone elastomers exhibit different swelling ratios in common organic solvents (2 mL). Fig 2 Fig. 3 The in-situ formed Ag@Silicone -catalyzed oxidation of hydrosilanes to silanols under optimization conditions (up) and Recyclability of the in-situ formed Ag@Silicone in the catalytic oxidation of hydrosilanes to silanols using MeOH as reagent (down). And the ICP-MS analysis revealed no silver leaching after the reaction. Fig 3 Fig. 4 The evaluation of recyclability of in-situ formed Ag@Silicone catalyst in the [3+2] cycloaddition reactions of aldiminoester 4 and 4-oxo-4-phenylbut-2-enoate 5. Fig 4 Scheme 1 Substrate scope of tandem conjugate addition−elimination reaction catalyzed by in-situ formed Ag@Silicone. Scheme 1 Fig. 5 Recyclability of the in-situ formed Ag@Silicone in the catalytic tandem conjugate addition−elimination reaction of glycine-derived aldimino ester 4a with MBH-type acetate 7a in Et2O. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Polysilicone-encapsulated Ag catalyst under different concentrations used for conjugate addition-elimination reaction of azomethine yelide with MBH acetate: 1) 2 mL; 2) 3 mL; 3) 4 mL; 4) 5 mL; 5) 6 mL; 6) 8 mL. Fig 6 Table 1. Reinforcing agent modified polysilicone-encapsulated Ag for 1,3-dipolar [3+2] cycloaddition of ethyl-4-oxo-phenylbut-2-enoate. China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contributed equally to this paper. The immobilization of molecular catalysts to fabricate heterogeneous catalysts for catalytic asymmetric transformations is extremely important and has attracted great attentions. Herein we developed a simple and new strategy for the heterogenization of homogeneous molecular complexes into the cross-linked polymer. It is demonstrated for the first time that the cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers can be applied for the swollen-induced in-situ encapsulation of homogeneous catalysts with or without chiral ligands. The swollen-induced in-situ encapsulation of silver catalyst system in the cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers led to the formation of silicone rubber-based hierarchically porous that could be used in asymmetric [3+2] cycloaddition, asymmetric tandem conjugate addition−elimination reaction and oxidation of hydrosilanes to silanols. The swollen-induced in-situ encapsulation of chiral silver complex in the cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers was proved to be easily recycled by filtration or pick-up and reused by several times. The simplest heterogeneous catalysis by the strategy of swollen-induced in-situ encapsulation can be extended to the encapsulation of chiral metal catalysts into different polymeric materials for the heterogenization of homogeneous catalysis. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Asymmetric catalysis Supported silver catalyst Organosilicon Encapsulation Homogeneous catalysis 1 Introduction The immobilization of molecular catalysts to fabricate heterogeneous catalysts for catalytic asymmetric transformations is extremely important in applied chemistry and chemical industry. [1] It is generally recognized as a convenient and renewed route for the facile preparation of organic molecules or polymeric materials due to the immiscible reaction partners that reacted at the surface of solid or interface of two liquids. [2] However, heterogeneous catalysts are usually less selectivity, necessitating harsher conditions with higher temperature or pressure, and could be substrate-sensitive in some cases. [3] Moreover, the recovered heterogeneous metal catalysts always have lower reactivity than that of freshly used homogeneous or heterogeneous catalysts. Therefore, although numerous methods have been explored in construction of various heterogeneous catalysts that have been well-documented in many reviews, it is really difficult to achieve an excellent or the same level of enantioselectivity in comparison to that with homogeneous catalysts. [4] And it should be noted that, the separation, recovery and reuse of chiral metal/P-ligand complex supported on heterogeneous materials are not easy as imagined. In the past decades, three immobilized strategies have been realized as privileged processes for the development of asymmetric heterogeneous catalysis (Fig. 1 ). For the type A or type B of heterogeneous catalysts shown in Fig. 1a, considerable effort has been directed towards immobilizing task-tailored metal catalysts onto immiscible inorganic or polymeric supports, [5] such as amorphous silica, [6] porous ordered materials, [7] and organic polymers. [8] For example, Xiao and co-workers [9] reported the construction of a highly efficient heterogeneous catalysts from the porous phosphoramidite ligand-based frameworks with Rh species. Liu, Mandolin, Nagashima, and our group [10] have found that the polysiloxane-supported organocatalysts exhibited as insoluble chiral catalysts with good to excellent enantioselectivity in dimerization of ketenes, reduction, Michael reaction, cyclopropanation, and aldol reaction respectively. And recent exploration supported that the use of chiral ligand-modified metal nanoparticles have come a promising strategy for the construction of active and robust catalyst systems (Fig. 1b). [11] In this regard, Kobayashi group contributed greatly to the development of asymmetric nanocatalysis. [12] We have also found that the Ar-BINMOL-Phos –modified copper(I) nanoparticles exhibited superior stereoselectivity in the catalytic asymmetric Huisgen cycloaddition of bis-alkynes in comparison to that of homogeneous system with the same chiral ligand. [13] In addition, heterogenization of homogeneous chiral catalysts in covalent organic frameworks (COF) [14] or metal-organic frameworks (MOF) [15] was also an effective strategy with enhanced catalytic performance for asymmetric catalysis (Fig. 1c). For example, Dong et al. [14b] reported the fabrication of palladium nanoparticles loaded on homochiral covalent organic framework that could promote the Henry reaction and reductive Heck reaction in high yields with excellent stereoselectivity. All these strategies provided the state-of-art of heterogenization of homogeneous chiral catalysts that is of paramount importance in asymmetric catalysis. Although various silicone-supported molecular catalysts have been established by several groups [16] in the past years, the complicated process for the preparation of a heterogeneous chiral catalyst is always unfavorable in the design of an ideal catalyst that features well-defined active sites with high activity and selectivity like homogeneous catalysts. Therefore, simple combination of the merits of homogeneous catalysis and heterogeneous catalysis by encapsulation of chiral metal catalysts in insoluble materials with space-confined nanoreactor will be expected to be conceptually new strategy. The visualization of the in-situ encapsulation of chiral silver catalysts in cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers is showed in Fig. 1d, in which the swollen silicone rubber possibly provides a hierarchically porous which can dramatically increase specific surface. During swelling of the cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers in solvent, the silicone rubber material will form large and small microchannels, and the microchannels can encapsulate a large amount of catalyst if possible. When the reaction solution with substrates flows in the silicone rubber, it appears to accomplish the reaction in hierarchically porous with Ag catalyst. Herein, we present our effort to the design of an innovative and broadly applicable strategy for swollen-induced encapsulation of chiral silver catalysts in the cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers that exhibit excellent performance in the catalytic asymmetric [3+2] cycloaddition and Michael reaction. Although silicone rubber is insoluble in most of organic solvents, it still has good swelling properties for some hydrocarbon solvents, such as toluene and diethyl ether. Because of different absorption capacity of silicone to solvents, the swollen-induced encapsulation of chiral metal complexes in the cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers will provide an opportunity for the determination of a new strategy for the heterogenization of homogeneous molecular catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 General methods All reagents and solvents were dried and purified before use by the usual procedures. Reactions were monitored by thin layer chromatography using silica gel. All the reactions dealing with air or moisture sensitive compounds were carried out in a dry reaction vessel under positive pressure of argon. Air- and moisture-sensitive liquids and solutions were transferred via a syringe or a stainless-steel cannula. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) observation was carried out using a JEOL JSM-6500F instrument operated at an accelerating voltage of 30 kV. 1H NMR was recorded at 400 MHz or 500 MHz: chemical shifts are reported in ppm relative to tetramethylsilane (TMS) with the solvent resonance employed as the internal standard (CDCl3 at 7.26 ppm). 13C NMR was recorded at 100 MHz or 126 MHz: chemical shifts are reported in ppm from tetramethylsilane (TMS) with the solvent resonance as the internal standard (CDCl3 at 77.20 ppm). Tetrahydrofuran (with Na and benzophenone) were freshly distilled in prior to use. The products 7 are known compounds that have been reported in our previous work. [19b] 2.2 General procedures for fabrication of cross-linked polysiloxane elastomer Cross-linked polysiloxane networks was fabricated by vinylsiloxane (viscosity 10000c St) and Polymethylhydrosiloxane (PMHS, H contenting: 0.18% and terminated by trimethylsiloxy groups at both ends), according to the reference 1. The reaction was carried out at 120 °C, under N2 atmosphere in the presence of Platinum(0)-1,3-divinyl-1,1,3,3-tetramethyldisiloxane complex (Karstedt`s catalyst). Molar ratios of Si-H groups to Si-CH=CH2 groups in the reaction was equal to 1.5:1. 2.3 General procedures for in-situ fabrication of ag@silicone catalysts and its application in catalytic transformations Ag@Silicone catalysts could be achieved from the cross-linked polysiloxane elastomer (3 g) in the presence of the mixed solution of AgOAc (10% mol/L) in diethyl ether (Et2O). The reactions were carried out at room temperature by stirring regents for 3 h and monitored using IR spectroscopy. After the reaction, the color of cross-linked polysiloxane elastomer was changed from colorless to dark black, the Ag nanoparticles polysiloxane elastomer was separated from the solution by centrifugation, washed with Et2O and dried on a vacuum. The prepared materials were characterized by Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) And this heterogeneous catalyst is directly used in the catalytic asymmetric reaction. 2.3.1 The general procedure for the silyl etherification of hydrosilane and alcohol catalyzed by ag@silicone/pph3 PPh3 (5.7 mg, 0.022 mmol) and AgOAc (1.6 mg, 0.01 mmol) were added to the reaction tube, and then 2 mL diethyl ether and 0.5 mL dichloromethane was added to above catalyst system and stirred at room temperature for about half an hour. Then the silicone rubber was added to the reaction mixture to absorb all the solvents. Subsequently, the hydrosilane (0.2 mmol) and alcohol (2 mL) was added to the reaction tube, and reacted at room temperature until the reaction is complete. The reaction solution was washed three times with ether, the reaction solution was collected, and filtered and purified. 2.3.2 The general experimental procedure for the use of ag@silicone/dtbm-segphos via swollen-induced in-situ encapsulation in catalytic 1,3-dipolar [3+2] cycloaddition reaction (R)-DTBM-Segphos (13 mg, 0.0108 mmol), AgOAc (1.6 mg, 0.0096 mmol) and chalcone (3.8 mg, 0.0182 mmol), and 2.0 mL of diethyl ether was added to the reaction mixture, and then stirred at room temperature for about 0.5 h. After that, silicone rubber was added to absorb above reaction mixture and stirred until the solvent is completely absorbed to the cross-linked silicone elastomer. Subsequently, the Schiff base 4 (0.20 mmol) and 4-oxo-4-phenylbut-2-enoate 5 (0.182 mmol) in 2 mL of diethyl ether were sequentially added, and the reaction was stirred at -40 °C overnight. After the completion of the reaction, the reaction solution was washed with diethyl ether three times and extracted with DCM three times. The reaction solution was collected and dried with anhydrous Na2SO4. After the solvent was removed by rotary evaporation under reduced pressure, the final product was separated by flash column chromatography. 2.3.3 General procedure for the use of ag@silicone/dtbm-segphos in catalytic tandem conjugate addition−elimination reaction of glycine-derived aldimino esters with MBH esters AgOAc (1.6 mg, 0.0096 mmol) and (R)-DTBM-Segphos (13 mg, 0.0108 mmol) were added to the reaction tube that has been treated with anhydrous and anaerobic conditions. Then 2.0 mL of diethyl ether was added above catalyst system and stirred at room temperature for about 0.5 h. silicone rubber was added and stirred until the solvent is completely absorbed to the cross-linked silicone elastomer. At -20 °C, substrate 4 (0.20 mmol) and K2CO3 (0.4 mmol) were added successively, and then add acetate 7 (0.22 mmol) to react overnight. After the reaction was completed, the reaction solution was washed three times with ether and extracted three times with DCM, the reaction solution was washed out and dried with anhydrous Na2SO4, and the solvent was removed by rotary evaporation under reduced pressure. The final product was separated by flash column chromatography. 3 Results and discussion Initially, we tested the adsorption capacity of the cross-linked silicone rubber to different solvents. The cross-linked polysilicone in this study was fabricated by the hydrosilylation reaction of vinylsiloxane and PMHS in the presence of platinum (0)-1,3-divinyl-1,1,3,3-tetramethyldisiloxane complex (Karstedt's catalyst, see the Supporting Information). The image of silicone elastomers and its adsorption capacity for different solvents is presented in Fig. 2 . As expected, we were pleased to find that the cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers exhibit different swelling performances in common organic solvents, including diethyl ether, methanol, toluene, tetrahydrofuran, ethyl acetate, dichloromethane. The diethyl ether (Et2O) exhibited the best penetration ability with (6.7 mL Et2O/g) to form a swollen silicone material that the diameter has doubled from 1 cm to 2 cm (Fig. 2b), and the ability of swollen as following: Et2O > THF > toluene > DCM ≈ EA > MeOH (Fig. 2d). Notably, the cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers exhibited almost no swelling properties in methanol, which would be beneficial to the extraction of Et2O from the silicon rubber. In addition, when the solution of AgOAc in Et2O was absorbed by the cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers, an in-situ formed black Ag@Silicone material was formed according to our hypothesis that the in-situ encapsulation of silver in swollen silicone elastomers occurred smoothly (Fig. 1c). We suggested that an instant reduction of Ag+ ions can be confirmed during the process by a fast coloration in black (Figure S1 of Supporting Information) because the residual Si-H groups on the cross-linked polysiloxane were generally proved to be a useful reducing agent. [17] We then checked the structure of in-situ formed Ag@Silicone material by FT-IR spectroscopy and scanning electron microscope (SEM). As shown in Figure S2 (Supporting Information), the partial reducing of AgOAc by hydrosilane on the polysilicone elastomer resulted into the formation of mixed Ag0/Ag+ cluster that indirectly proved by FT-IR spectroscopy. In general, the Si-H bond stretching vibrations are located at 2160 cm−1. Whereas, after the encapsulation of AgOAc in the cross-linked silicone rubber, the intensities of peak at 2160 cm−1 decreased dramatically when the use of various silver salts in Et2O, and the peak at 2160 cm−1 almost disappeared in the presence of AgOAc with or without PPh3. Therefore, these results suggested that the residual Si-H groups in the cross-linked silicone were used as a reducing promoter to enhance the encapsulation of Ag/PPh3 complex. The morphology of in-situ formed Ag@Silicone material by SEM analysis shown in Figure S3 (Supporting Information) also supported that the silver was very evenly dispersed in the silicone rubber, in which the encapsulation of silver catalyst in the cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers was proved to be a facile process. And the structural stability of the Ag@Silicone material was established by evaporation drying and subsequent reswelling in Et2O. Then we examined the catalytic activity of the in-situ formed Ag@Silicone in the oxidation of hydrosilanes to silanols that is one of the most important Si-based molecules in organosilicon chemistry. [18] When the in-situ encapsulated catalyst, Ag@Silicone that absorbed with AgOAc in Et2O in the cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers, was used in the oxidation of hydrosilanes with methanol or ethanol under mild conditions, the reaction was accomplished smoothly to give the desired product with >95% yield. Notably, the reaction operation is very simple because the in-situ formed Ag@Silicone with swelling Et2O and loading silver immersed in methanol solution could be directly picked up from the liquid after the oxidation reaction was completed. Moreover, the recyclability of Ag@Silicone was performed with hydrosilane and MeOH under the same conditions. The experimental results indicated that the cross-linked polysiloxane-encapsulated Ag catalyst could be reusable for at least five times with excellent yields in the oxidation reaction of dimethylphenylhydrosilane (Fig. 3 ), revealing an excellent stability. Thus, it is reasonable to suggest that the encapsulation of silver catalyst in the cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers could be utilized as a new strategy to reuse chiral catalyst in enantioselective transformations. Inspired by our previous studies on the asymmetric silver catalysis, [19] we checked the [3+2] cycloaddition reactions of aldiminoester 4a and 4-oxo-4-phenylbut-2-enoate 5a in the presence of (R)-DTBM-SegPhos under reported conditions except the solvent. [19a] The desired product 3a was obtained in 49% yield with 73% ee for the first time. And the cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers or Ag@Silicone catalyst in silicon rubber was reused in the next cycle (Fig. 4 ). It should be noted that the recyclable silicone -encapsulated Ag catalyst was easily recovered from the reaction solution through filtration and washed with Et2O. The silicone rubber with Ag complex was dried on vacuum and reused without the addition of (R)-DTBM-SegPhos or any further treatment. The gradual decrease in the enantioselectivity was observed because of the partial oxidation of chiral P-ligand during the work-up. And we found that other SiO2- or cinchona alkaloid-modified silicone rubbers were not suitable for the encapsulation of chiral silver complex owing to low conversion in the next run. These results (Table 1 ) provided indirect evidence that the use of some solid additives, including silicon dioxide (SiO2), carbon black (CB), white carbon black (WCB), cinchonine (CN), are likely to affect the formation of hierarchically porous because of its no recyclability in this reaction, thereby hindering the free flow of the reaction fluid in the microchannel of silicone rubber. Notably, only pure silicone elastomer without any additive resulted into at least three times to reuse this chiral catalyst system. Thus, for the silicone-encapsulated Ag@Silicone catalyst coordinated with chiral P-ligand (DTBM-SegPhos), the reaction results are similar to that of homogeneous reaction system under the same conditions, implying that the chirality or molecular structure of Ag/DTBM-SegPhos is well maintained during the swollen-induced in-situ encapsulation. Encouraged by the experimental results presented Fig. 4, we continue to establish a catalytic asymmetric tandem conjugate addition−elimination reaction of glycine-derived aldimino ester 4 with MBH-type acetate 7 that promoted by Ag/DTBM-SegPhos. Having established the optimal reaction conditions with homogeneous reaction system that reported in our previous work [19b], we investigated the in-situ formed Ag@Silicone –catalyzed conjugate addition−elimination reaction in the presence of chiral P-ligand, (R)-DTBM-SegPhos (The substrate scope was summarized in Scheme 1 ). The experiment results supported that a wide range of substrates bearing electron-rich, electron-deficient or electron-neutral groups on the phenyl ring could afford the corresponding products 8 in good yields with excellent enantioselectivities (97–99% ees), implying that no substrate-sensitive phenomena is observed. In other words, the microchannel of swollen silicone rubber provided a micro-environment with enough size of hollow for the transformation of large molecules. Then we checked the recyclability of the in-situ formed Ag@Silicone catalyst and found it could be reused for at least five runs with almost the same high level of yields and excellent enantioselectivities (94–96% ees, see Fig. 5 and Table S2). In order to evaluate the stability of silver catalyst that in-situ encapsulated in the cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers, the tandem conjugate addition−elimination reaction was examined by the in-situ formed Ag@Silicone catalyst under different concentrations (Fig. 6 ). The screening process showed that the same level of yield and excellent enantioselectivity (97% ee) could be achieved under different concentrations, which indirectly indicated that no silver catalyst existed in homogenous reaction system outside the silicone rubber, and the catalytic asymmetric reaction only occurred in the hierarchically porous. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have successfully developed a sustainable and convenient strategy that focused on the development of an in-situ silicone-encapsulated Ag catalyst through swollen-induced encapsulation for asymmetric [3+2] cycloaddition, asymmetric tandem conjugate addition−elimination reaction and oxidation of hydrosilanes to silanols. It is demonstrated for the first time that the cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers can be applied for the in-situ encapsulation of homogeneous catalysts with or without chiral ligands. The swollen-induced in-situ encapsulation of silver catalyst system in the cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers led to the formation of hierarchically porous that could be easily recycled by filtration or pick-up and reused by several times. Meanwhile, the in-situ formed Ag@Silicone catalyst systems used in related reactions provide the following merits: i) a direct and effective method that with catalyst absorbed in the solid phase and substrate reacted in the liquid phase for catalytic asymmetric [3+2] cycloaddition resulted into moderate yield and good enantioselectivity, in which the catalyst was shown to be recyclable at least four runs without any observable decrease. ii) an efficient asymmetric tandem conjugate addition−elimination reaction was demonstrated and the catalyst system exhibits excellent performance that could be reused at least five runs with almost the same high level of yields and excellent enantioselectivities 94–96% ees. Overall, it could be recognized as the simplest heterogeneous catalysis by the in-situ encapsulation of metal catalyst in cross-linked polymer, and it is a general strategy that can be easily extended to the development of heterogenization of homogeneous catalysts for the sustainable productions of fine chemicals and chiral pharmaceuticals in chemical industry. coredata.dc:description: The immobilization of molecular catalysts to fabricate heterogeneous catalysts for catalytic asymmetric transformations is extremely important and has attracted great attentions. Herein we developed a simple and new strategy for the heterogenization of homogeneous molecular complexes into the cross-linked polymer. It is demonstrated for the first time that the cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers can be applied for the swollen-induced in-situ encapsulation of homogeneous catalysts with or without chiral ligands. The swollen-induced in-situ encapsulation of silver catalyst system in the cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers led to the formation of silicone rubber-based hierarchically porous that could be used in asymmetric [3+2] cycloaddition, asymmetric tandem conjugate addition−elimination reaction and oxidation of hydrosilanes to silanols. The swollen-induced in-situ encapsulation of chiral silver complex in the cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers was proved to be easily recycled by filtration or pick-up and reused by several times. The simplest heterogeneous catalysis by the strategy of swollen-induced in-situ encapsulation can be extended to the encapsulation of chiral metal catalysts into different polymeric materials for the heterogenization of homogeneous catalysis.
coredata.dc:title: Swollen-induced in-situ encapsulation of chiral silver catalysts in cross-linked polysiloxane elastomers: Homogeneous reaction and heterogeneous separation
